subject: Re: [junit] Proposition (?) [WAS Re: Why doesn't JUnit count asserts]
msgSnippet: ... exectuted if you don t change the Assert class. Of course, even if the counting is not done in the assert class, the assert class still has to be modified
messageBody:
>Otherwise, I don't see how you can know when an assertion is beeing
exectuted if you don't change the Assert class.

Of course, even if the counting is not done in the assert class, the assert
class still has to be modified to emit the an event or something similar.

mathieu

----- Original Message -----
From: Vladimir Bossicard
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Tuesday, July 24, 2001 6:13 PM
Subject: Re: [junit] Proposition (?) [WAS Re: Why doesn't JUnit count
asserts]


> "Have a way easily to configure assert-counting with a maximum increase in
> execution speed of 1%"

if you modify the Assert class, it's not a problem (if you want the code I
have it...). But you have to change the framework and it's not pluggable.
Otherwise, I don't see how you can know when an assertion is beeing
exectuted if you don't change the Assert class.

-Vladimir
